title: Working backward to solve problems - Maurice Ashley

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the techniques used by grandmasters to look ahead in chess?

options.label: A
options.text: Chunking, which involves taking a group of chess pieces and seeing what possibilities can come from it.

options.label: B
options.text: Pattern recognition, which involves going over a lot of positions that look very similarly and extrapolating truths from that.

options.label: C
options.text: Stepping-stone method, which involves taking a position and going from there to guess the next position.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind retrograde analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: To look ahead in a chess game by analyzing the position of the pieces.

options.label: B
options.text: To look backwards in a chess game by analyzing the position of the pieces.

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze the position of the pieces in a chess game by going forward and backward.

options.label: D
options.text: To analyze the position of the pieces in a chess game by using intuition.

multiple-choice.question: Why is retrograde analysis useful in solving chess puzzles?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it allows grandmasters to see 10-15 moves ahead.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows grandmasters to analyze the position of the pieces in a chess game by going forward and backward.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it allows grandmasters to see the end game of a chess game.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it allows grandmasters to use intuition to solve chess puzzles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the answer to the problem "Bacteria that double every 24 hours fill a lake it has infested after precisely 60 days. On what day was the lake half-full?"

options.label: A
options.text: Because it allows you to see the sentence in a new way.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows you to catch mistakes that you might have missed the first time around.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it allows you to use your intuition to solve the problem.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it allows you to use a calculator to solve the problem.

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: Vestigial structures

multiple-choice.question: What does Charles Darwin suggest that vestigial structures are?

options.label: A
options.text: They are organs that are still useful for humans.

options.label: B
options.text: They are physical evidence of our ancestors' past use for certain body parts.

options.label: C
options.text: They are organs that are only found in animals.

options.label: D
options.text: They are organs that are only found in plants.

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: To warn predators to stay away.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the animal look bigger.

options.label: D
options.text: To help the animal breathe.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It is a vestige of a tail and is still useful for balance.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a vestige of a tail and is no longer useful but is still present.

multiple-choice.question: Why do humans have wisdom teeth?

options.label: B
options.text: Because our jaws are too small to accommodate all of the teeth that grow into them.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are vestigial structures.

options.label: B
options.text: A vestige of a past use for the eye.

options.label: C
options.text: A membrane that hangs out in the corner of the eye.

options.label: D
options.text: A membrane that helps to regulate body temperature.

options.text: Attending to details

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A person who is good at language, but struggles with math

options.label: C
